Lesson1.Error: Seems like you didn't print the working directory.  Try again.
Lesson1.Hint: You want to Print the Working Directory to continue.
Lesson1.Instructions: pwd (print working directory): This command will return the path of the directory you are currently in.
Lesson1.Question: Print out the current working directory.
Lesson1.Title: Print Working Directory

Lesson2.Error: Seems like you didn't type 'ls'.  Try again.
Lesson2.Instructions: ls is used to display the contents of a directory. It is an extremely useful command that you'll use all the time, so get use to it!
Lesson2.Question: Display the contents of the current directory..
Lesson2.Title: List Directory / Files

Lesson3.Error: Seems like you didn't type change your directory to 'usa'.  Try again.
Lesson3.Hint: You need to Change the Directory to 'usa' continue.
Lesson3.Instructions: cd (change directory): This command accepts arguments in the form of file structure in order to traverse the system.  For example: 'cd usa' will change your working directory to /BustinBash/usa'.
Lesson3.Question: Change your current directory to /usa
Lesson3.Title: Change Directory

Lesson4.Error: Seems like you didn't traverse up one level in your directory.  Try again.
Lesson4.Instructions: You can change up directories by using the 'cd' command combined with the '..' syntax. This will move up on level in your directory tree. You can travel up as many levels as you want. For example, to travel up three levels, you would type: 'cd ../../../'
Lesson4.Question: Change your current directory to /BustinBash
Lesson4.Title: Change Directory

Lesson5.Error: Seems like you didn't navigate to the proper directory.  Try again.
Lesson5.Hint: Please change to the '/usa/ca/san_francisco' directory to continue.
Lesson5.Instructions: You can cd into a directory fast by specifiying the path to that folder. If I wanted to cd into newyork_city I would type 'cd usa/ny/newyork_city'.
Lesson5.Question: Change directories to san_francisco'.
Lesson5.Title: Change Directory

Lesson6.Error: Seems like you didn't create a directory called 'marin'.  Try again!
Lesson6.Hint: You'll want to make use of the 'mkdir' command
Lesson6.Instructions: Creating directories is an integral part of using Bash. A directory is a folder on your computer that contains other folders and files. To create a new directory we use the 'mkdir' command followed by the directory name.
Lesson6.Question: Make a new directory in the san_francisco directory called marin.
Lesson6.Title: Make Directory

Lesson7.Error: Seems like you didn't delete the directory correctly.  Try again.
Lesson7.Hint: Please delete the directory marin to continue.
Lesson7.Instructions: You can remove a folder easily with 'rmdir' followed by the directory name.
Lesson7.Question: Delete the marin directory
Lesson7.Title: Remove Directory

Lesson8.Error: Seems like you didn't type the command correctly.  Try again.
Lesson8.Hint: try typing something like 'echo your sentence here.'
Lesson8.Instructions: The command 'echo' is used display text to the console. For example, '$echo Hey Universe' prints 'Hey Universe' to the screen. This is an example of Bash's STDOUT, or Standard Output, which is the output of a command.
Lesson8.Question: Print 'Bustin Bash' out to the console.
Lesson8.Title: echo/STDOUT

Lesson9.Error: oops! Looks like you didn't create a new file called the_bay.txt
Lesson9.Hint: just type touch then the filename to create a new file
Lesson9.Instructions: You can create new files easily with the touch command. Creating a new file is super easy! Just type 'touch' then the name of the file you would like to create.
Lesson9.Question: Create a new file called the_bay.txt
Lesson9.Title: touch
